productionPhases.phase: Phase 1: Earth, Space & Initial Hell's Gate Ops
keyConstraints: Sequenced to accommodate staggered cast arrivals (Saldana, Weaver, Lang).
Front-loads non-mocap scenes to allow for extended performance capture system calibration.
Completes all work for actors not required in New Zealand.
Scheduled entirely within the optimal dry season (Oct-Mar).
Heavy focus on bioluminescent night shoots, requiring careful crew turnaround management.

productionPhases.phase: Phase 3: Peak Performance Capture & Final Battle
keyConstraints: Groups all remaining technologically revolutionary sequences (Hometree, Floating Mountains, Final Battle, Tree of Souls).
Maximizes use of the mature VFX pipeline.
Structured to accommodate Sigourney Weaver's May 15 stop date.

days.notes: Company move to ISV Venture Star Sets
First day on location, daylight creature interaction sequences
First night shoot, bioluminescent forest setup

laborCosts.notes: Significant overtime is projected for Phase 2 (New Zealand night shoots) and Phase 3 (complex final battle sequences). Budget for 35% overtime/penalty payments above standard rates.

efficiencySavings.notes: Grouping all New Zealand work into a single block saves an estimated $2.5M in company move and equipment shipping costs. Front-loading non-mocap work reduces hold days for high-cost mocap crew, saving an estimated $800k.

additionalCosts.notes: Budget an additional $1.2M for weather contingency in New Zealand. A dedicated logistics team for coordinating the 2,500 Na'vi performers is a critical, unbudgeted but necessary cost.

riskFactors.mitigation: Schedule a 2-week 'burn-in' period for the virtual production pipeline before principal photography. Retain key Weta Digital engineers on-site throughout Phase 3. Add 5 floating tech contingency days to the schedule.
Schedule is correctly placed in the October-March dry season. The 8 built-in contingency days are essential. A secondary, covered, partial set should be prepped for minor weather events.

Strictly enforce 6-day work weeks and 12-hour turnarounds, especially during night shoots and mocap-intensive blocks. Schedule a full 'stand-down' week after the New Zealand shoot concludes to allow cast and crew to recover before starting the final VFX phase.

Coordinating 2,000+ performers for Hometree scenes is the single biggest logistical risk. A dedicated 'Mass Performer Unit' with its own AD team must be established. Rehearsals must be staggered in groups of 200.

recommendations: IMMEDIATE ACTION: Lock in the New Zealand location permits and key department heads (Location Manager, NZ-based 1st AD) immediately due to the tight seasonal window and international competition for resources.

STRATEGIC INVESTMENT: Approve the budget for a secondary, smaller mocap volume. This allows for splinter unit work on props, secondary characters, or creature cycles, de-risking the critical path dependence on the main volume.
CREW WELFARE: Plan for and budget a mid-shoot hiatus between Phase 2 (NZ) and Phase 3 (LA) to mitigate crew and cast fatigue on this exceptionally long and demanding production schedule.
